selected_quotes: Nice work on effectiveness of travelller screening for infectious diseases-Gostic,@AdamJKucharski,Lloyd-Smith @elife
Airport screening for disease ineffective- Katelyn Gostic talks
Interesting modeling of infections which has application for screening decisions done at airports
Airport epidemic contagion screening. detection was typically possible ONLY by risk factor questionnaire screening.

citation.title: Effectiveness of traveller screening for emerging pathogens is shaped by epidemiology and natural history of infection

news.title: Airport screening misses more than half of infected travelers, study says
news.summary: Scary news if you are flying any time soon: Airport screening procedures to stop the spread of infectious diseases miss half to three-quarters of infected travelers who make it to their destinations, according to a new university study.

news.title: Airport screening misses half of disease cases but could be improved
news.summary: Researchers have found that in order to be effective, the screening of passengers for disease at airports must be tailored to the outbreak in question.

news.title: Airport screening misses half of disease cases but could be improved
news.summary: Scientists have shown that airport screening for disease will often miss half or more of infected travellers, but can be improved by customizing to pathogens.

news.title: Airport screening misses half of disease cases but could be improved
news.summary: Scientists have shown that airport screening for disease will often miss half or more of infected travellers, but can be improved by customizing to pathogens. The findings are published in the journal eLife.

news.title: Airport screening misses half of disease cases but could be improved by customizing to pathogens
news.summary: Airport screening for infectious disease such as Ebola, bird flu and SARS will often miss half or more of infected travellers, but can be improved, according to new researched published in the journal eLife.

news.title: Airport Screening Misses Half of Infectious Disease Cases but Could Be Improved

news.title: Airport screening for viruses misses half of infected travelers but can be improved, says UCLA-led study
news.summary: In the past decade, the H1N1 virus and Ebola are just two of the diseases whose spread was spurred by international airline travel. Screening passengers at airports, therefore, could be one key method for slowing the global spread of infectious diseases.

blogs.summary: Screening travelers for fever on arrival has been criticized as ineffective, but the scientists found it can catch cases that screeners miss at departure.

facebook.title: Airport screening for ebola and other diseases "inherently leaky".
facebook.summary:
Researchers from UCLA and the LSHTM have identified ways to make current airport disease screening as effective as possible and have highlighted what needs to be done next to improve it further. 

Here, lead author Katelyn Gostic talks to the BBC World Ser
